note:
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
morphine
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Multiple falls, transferred from ___ with cholangitis
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Endoscopies (ERCP/EUS/EGD) ___

 
History of Present Illness:
___ PMH type 2 diabetes, arthritis, hypertension, HLD, atrial
fibrillation on Eliquis, transferred from ___ for
multiple fall injuries subsequently found to have cholangitis.
Her workup there included negative CT head. CT A/P revealed CBD
dilation and sludge/?stones distal CBD. She was given vancomycin
and zosyn. She was found to have atrial fibrillation with RVR,
requiring a diltiazem drip. 

In the ED, initial VS were 97.8 92 120/63 20 96% on RA.
Labs notable for WBC of 16.5, plt 130. BMP with Cr of 1.2. LFTS
with ALT 315, AST 392, Alk Phos 422, T. bili 2.9. Lipase 170. 
The patient was initially on a diltiazem drip which was
subsequently discontinued. The patient was started on IV Zosyn. 

Upon arrival to the floor, the patient tells the story as
follows. Patient states she has had multiple fall injuries due 
to
weakness while getting up from a chair. She denies head strike
and loss of consciousness. She feels that her "legs gave out."
She endorses epigastric pain or pressure, without difficulty
eating, without nausea. She denies chest pain, difficulty
breathing, dyspnea on exertion, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea,
constipation, or dysuria. She denies recent fevers or chills. 
Her
atrial fibrillation is asymptomatic for her and not accompanied
by dizziness or lightheadedness or palpitations.

She also reports worsening lower extremity edema. She reports 
the
edema has extended to above her knees and has made it difficult
for her to walk. She reports that she takes torsemide every day
but denies any prior diagnosis of heart failure.

ROS: Pertinent positives and negatives as noted in the HPI.  All
other systems were reviewed and are negative. 

 
Past Medical History:
- Type 2 DM
- Arthritis
- HTN
- HLD
- Atrial fibrillation on Eliquis
- Appendectomy
- Prior L ankle fracture with rods
- Hysterectomy
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
+MI in son, + CHF in father, + stroke in father, + CHF in mother
 
Physical ___:
ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM:
VITALS: Afebrile and vital signs stable (see eFlowsheet)
GENERAL: Alert and in no apparent distress
EYES: Anicteric, pupils equally round
ENT: Ears and nose without visible erythema, masses, or trauma. 
Oropharynx without visible lesion, erythema or exudate
Mucous membranes moist 
CV: Heart irregular, no murmur
RESP: crackles in bilateral lung base
GI: Abdomen soft, non-distended, tender to palpation in the RUQ
and epigastric region
GU: foley in place
MSK: Neck supple, moves all extremities, strength grossly full
and symmetric bilaterally in all limbs
SKIN: No rashes or ulcerations noted
NEURO: Alert, oriented, face symmetric, gaze conjugate with 
EOMI,
speech fluent, moves all limbs
PSYCH: pleasant, appropriate affect

DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAM:
GENERAL: Alert and interactive
EYES: Anicteric, pupils equally round
ENT: Ears and nose without visible erythema, masses, or trauma. 
MMMs
CV: irregular
RESP: Lungs clear to auscultation with good air movement
bilaterally, mild bibasilar crackles.  
GI: Abdomen soft, non-distended, non-tender to palpation.
SKIN: Scattered ecchymoses
EXTR: wwp mild/moderate BLE edema
NEURO: Alert, interactive, face symmetric, gaze conjugate with
EOMI, speech fluent, motor function grossly intact/symmetric
PSYCH: patient tearful at times about her overall condition and 
concerned about her ability to improve

MICRO:
=======
BCx: ___: CONS ___ bottles
BCx: ___: NO GROWTH
BCx: ___ X2, ___: NO GROWTH TO DATE

IMAGING/STUDIES:
================

EGD ___
-normal mucosa throughout, metal stent examined without evidence
of bleeding

ERCP ___: post-sphincterotomy bleed. Successful hemostasis with 
bicap and fully covered metal stent

EUS ___: choledocholithiasis with dilated CBD to 1.3 cm

ERCP ___: Successful ERCP with sphincterotomy and extraction of 
stones as described above.

ERCP ___: Difficult ERCP with unsuccessful cannulation. A 
hydratome with both straight and angled 0.35 wires were used and 
unable to cannulate. A Olympus sphincterotome with a 0.025 
angled wire was unsuccessful. A pre-cut sphincterotomy was 
performed, which resulted in mild oozing, treated with 
epinephrine 0.3 mg. Despite pre-cut sphincterotomy, we were 
unable to identify the biliary tract and the procedure was 
aborted. Hemostasis was achieved at the end of the procedure

TTE ___ left atrial volume index is SEVERELY increased. 
There is no evidence for an atrial septal defect by 2D/color 
Doppler. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy 
with a normal cavity size. There is mildmoderate global left 
ventricular hypokinesis. The left ventricular apex is heavily 
trabeculated, but without definte thrombus. There is 
beat-to-beat variability in the left ventricular contractility 
due to the irregular rhythm. The visually estimated left 
ventricular ejection fraction is 35-45%. There is no resting 
left ventricular outflow tract gradient. Mildly dilated right 
ventricular cavity with normal free wall motion. Tricuspid 
annular plane systolic excursion (TAPSE) is normal. The aortic 
sinus diameter is normal for gender with mildly dilated 
ascending aorta. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly 
thickened. There is no aortic valve stenosis. There is no aortic 
regurgitation. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened 
with no mitral valve prolapse.
There is mild to moderate [___] mitral regurgitation. The 
pulmonic valve leaflets are normal. The tricuspid valve leaflets 
are mildly thickened. There is moderate [2+] tricuspid 
regurgitation. There is mild-moderate
pulmonary artery systolic hypetension. There is no pericardial 
effusion.
IMPRESSION: Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with 
mild to moderate global hypokinesis (consistent with a 
non-ischemic cardiomyopathy). Mildly dilated right ventricle 
with normal free wall systolic function. Moderate tricuspid 
regurgitation with mild to moderate
pulmnonary hypertension.

Chest XR ___
FINDINGS:  
There are low bilateral lung volumes.  Small bilateral pleural 
effusions are present with subjacent atelectasis and/or 
consolidation.  No pneumothorax.  The size of the cardiac 
silhouette is mildly enlarged but unchanged. 
IMPRESSION:  
Small bilateral pleural effusions with subjacent atelectasis 
and/or pneumonia. 

Thoracic and Lumbar Spine XR ___
FINDINGS:  
There is a mild dextroconvex curvature centered at the upper 
thoracic spine as well as a mild S shaped curvature of the 
lumbar spine.  The bones are diffusely osteopenic.  There is no 
acute compression deformity visualized.  Multilevel degenerative 
changes are present throughout the thoracic and lumbar spines, 
most prominent at L2-L3.  A right iliac vascular stent is 
present.  There is heavy calcification of the abdominal aorta.  
The visualized portion of the lungs and cardiomediastinal 
silhouette are within normal limits. 
IMPRESSION:  
No acute compression deformity of the thoracic or lumbar spine.  
Multilevel degenerative changes, most prominent at L2-L3. 

CT CSPINE ___. No evidence of traumatic cervical mal-alignment or acute
fracture. 
2. Minimal anterolisthesis of C2 on C3 and C7 on T1 is felt to 
be
degenerative in nature. 
3. Heterogeneous thyroid gland with multiple rounded
hypodensity/lesions, measuring up to 2 cm. Further assessment
with dedicated thyroid ultrasound is recommended. 
4. Partially imaged right-sided pleural effusion 

Review of ___ Records:
Pelvic xray: Radiographically intact pelvis. 
CXR: Interstitial opacities suggestive of CHF versus 
atelectasis/
interstitial pneumonia. 
CT A/P: Distended gallbladder, intra and extraheptic biliary 
tree
likely due to distal CBD stones and sludge. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
SUMMARY:
___ yo F PMHx atrial fibrillation on Eliquis, recurrent falls who 
came in transfer from ___ where she initially 
presented with falls but was found to have CBD dilation and 
sludge/stones concerning for cholangitis. She was treated with 
ceftriaxone and metronidazole for a total of 14 days (___) 
and underwent ERCP x2 with sphincterotomy and biliary sludge 
removal. Her hospital course was complicated by 
post-sphincterotomy bleeding s/p cauterization and metal stent 
placement with resolution of bleeding, afib with RVR, acute CHF 
exacerbation requiring diuresis, worsening of her chronic back 
pain, and deconditioning.

# Choledocholithiasis, Cholangitis s/p ERCP c/b 
post-sphincterotomy bleed
# Acute blood loss anemia and iron deficiency
Patient presenting with RUQ abdominal pain, reported fever, and 
CT scan with CBD dilatation and sludge/stones. Initial ERCP 
unsuccessful. Repeat successful on ___ with removal of sludge 
and visualization of gallstones in dilated CBD to 13mm. LFTs 
downtrended. Patient evaluated by general surgery who did not 
think she would be a candidate for cholecystectomy given her age 
and comorbidities, combined with the fact that recurrent 
episodes are less likely after sphincterotomy. She was treated 
with ceftriaxone and metronidazole for a total of 14 days (d1 
___ - ___.
Of note, her hospital course was complicated by 
post-sphincterotomy bleeding with 1.5gm Hgb drop, requiring 
repeat intervention for control of active bleeding and stent 
placement. She subsequently had several days of continued 
downtrending in her hemoglobin, which initially raised concern 
for continued bleeding. However a repeat EGD on ___ showed no 
further bleeding, and her hemoglobin subsequent stabilized 
around 8. Her apixaban was restarted ___ and hemoglobin 
remained stable the next ___ hours. She received 1 U RBCs and 
also received 2 doses of IV ferric gluconate (125 mg) for a 
component of iron defiency. 

# Atrial fibrillation with RVR: 
Patient required diltiazem drip in the ED. While on the medical 
floor, she triggered for RVR in setting of fluid overload, 
infection. Her diltiazem was fractionated and increased to 60 mg 
q6hr with improvement in rate control. However given her new 
diagnosis of systolic heart failure, her AV nodal blockade was 
subsequently transitioned to metoprolol. She was discharged on 
150 mg metoprolol succinate daily, which may require further 
titration. Her anticoagulation was held for much of the 
admission given concern for bleeding. It was restarted on ___ 
without any evidence of ongoing bleeding based on her hemoglobin 
trend. (Of note, stool remained dark brown, but not black or 
melenic appearing.)

# Acute on chronic systolic heart failure (new diagnosis) 
# ___
On admission, patient with lower extremity edema and CXR with 
pulmonary edema, consistent with CHF. She denies history of CHF, 
however TTE here w/ EF 35-45% and global hypokinesis c/w NICM. 
She was diuresed with 40-80 mg iv Lasix to good effect (12 lb 
weight drop). She was started on low dose lisinopril in setting 
of hypertension and low EF. Her AV nodal blockade was changed to 
metoprolol as per above. Her diuresis was held during the days 
prior to discharge due to concern for intravascular volume 
depletion, although her peripheral edema persisted. Her 
torsemide was restarted on ___, but on ___ her creatinine 
increased from 0.9 to 1.2, and so the torsemide was held at 
discharge, with plan for close monitoring of labs and volume 
status and determination of when to restart this in rehab. 

# Acute on chronic back pain
# Difficulty coping
Patient has significant chronic back pain, which was worse in 
the setting of her prolonged admission and reduced activity. 
This was noted to improve with analgesics and with working with 
___. She also struggled in coping with her pain, as well as fecal 
and urinary incontinence and being far from home. She will be 
discharged to rehab much closer to home, which will hopefully 
address all of these issues. Her oxycodone and flexeril can be 
weaned as tolerated while in rehab. Tylenol and lidocaine 
patched can be continued. 

# Mechanical falls: 
Patient originally presented with weakness and multiple 
mechanical falls in the setting of acute illness as above. CT 
head negative. CT neck without traumatic injury. Pelvis xray 
without fracture. X-ray knees with severe DJD bilaterally. Pain 
waxed and wane in lumbar spine and knees and was treated 
symptomatically with lidocaine patches, oxycodone and scheduled 
Tylenol.  Her home dose of oxycodone was increased to 
accommodate worsening pain in the hospital setting.

# DM: held home Glimepiride 2 mg daily while in hospital. 
Maintained on HISS. Restarted at discharge

# Hyperlipidemia: continued home atorvastatin 40 mg daily

# Positive blood culture:
At ___, ___ BCx positive for CONS. Initially treated with 
vancomycin, however cultures at ___ with no growth 
and remaining cultures at ___ also with no growth, thus 
thought to be contamination. 

#Thyroid nodules: 
"Heterogeneous thyroid gland with multiple rounded 
hypodensity/lesions, measuring up to 2 cm." Ultrasound follow up 
recommended. ___ College of Radiology guidelines recommend 
further evaluation for incidental thyroid nodules of 1.0 cm or 
larger in patients under age ___ or 1.5 cm in patients age ___ or 
___, or with suspicious findings. Patient's daughter and 
patient informed. 

#Outpatient follow-up
Patient has cardiology appointment for establishment of care at 
___ next week. Her daughter is also interested in looking into 
a local cardiologist, possibly at ___. Unclear whether 
patient will be following up with current PCP or establishing 
with a new PCP, possibly at ___.

===================================
===================================

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
======================

[] torsemide held on day of discharge due to bump in creatinine 
from 0.9->1.2 after it was restarted on ___. 
 - please obtain daily or every other day BMP until renal 
function improved
 - monitor weights, edema, and consider restarted torsemide 
again once appropriate (likely will also need potassium 
restarted at that time)

[] check CBC twice weekly and watch for any signs of recurrent 
GI bleed

[] Continue to titrate metoprolol and lisinopril based on vital 
signs. if worsening rate control is refractory to increase in 
metoprolol could consider adding back diltiazem

[] wean oxycodone and flexeril as able 

[] Received 2 doses of Ferric Gluconate for iron deficiency. 
Would check iron studies as outpatient and can consider PO iron 
vs further IV iron (would hold off on PO for now to avoid 
potential red herring for recurrent GI bleed)

[] Will need extraction and possible replacement of metal stent 
via ERCP in 6 weeks. (Should be contacted by ERCP team to 
schedule)

[] Thyroid nodules: Seen on imaging here. Ultrasound follow up 
recommended. ___ College of Radiology guidelines recommend 
further evaluation for incidental
thyroid nodules of 1.0 cm or larger in patients under age ___ or 
1.5 cm in patients age ___ or ___, or with suspicious findings.
 
[] Patient would benefit from orthopedics or pain evaluation for 
management of severe osteoarthritis

[] Possible establishment with new PCP after rehab. Has 
cardiology appointment at ___ in ___, but may also be 
interested in seeing cardiologist at ___ or other local 
provider

[] if continued difficulty with coping may benefit from mental 
health referral

===================================
===================================

>30 minutes in patient care and coordination of discharge

Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
PRIMARY
Ascending cholangitis with obstruction
Gastrointestinal bleeding
Anemia
Acute on chronic systolic heart failure exacerbation (new 
diagnosis)
Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response
Osteoarthritis
Long term use of opioid medication
Diabetes

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms ___,

You came to the hospital in transfer from ___ 
because you were found to have an infection in the bile ducts 
and gallbladder called cholangitis. We gave you antibiotics and 
treated you with a procedure called 'ERCP' which removed a 
gallstone that was causing the infection. Unfortunately, you 
developed bleeding after the procedure and had to have another 
procedure to stop the bleeding. 

While you were in the hospital, we also noticed that you had 
extra fluid build-up in your body (swelling in the lower legs 
and fluid in the lungs). You had an ultrasound of your heart 
which showed that you have 'heart failure' - a decrease in the 
pumping function of the heart. We used medications to remove 
some of the extra fluid while you were in the hospital. You will 
need to have a cardiologist moving forward. 

We have outlined a number of follow-up issues for your future 
doctors in your ___ paperwork. Amongst these issues are 
the following:
- you will need an ultrasound to evaluate some nodules that were 
seen in your thyroid gland
- you will need ongoing adjustments to your heart medications 
and water pills
- you may benefit from evaluation by a pain specialist
- you will need a repeat "ERCP" endoscopy procedure to remove 
your stent in about 6 weeks

Please continue to work on getting stronger in rehab. If you 
develop any more black stools, abdominal pain, fevers, nausea, 
chest pain or trouble breathing, please go to the nearest 
Emergency Room immediately.

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your hospital stay 
at ___.  We wish you the best!

Sincerely,
Your ___ Team
 
Followup Instructions:
___

qafib.question: Does the note describe the patient as having permanent, paroxysmal, or persistent afib?

qprior_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having a stroke or transient ischemic attack?

qarterial_hypertension.question: Does the note describe the patient as having arterial hypertension on treatment (high bp e.g. >140, or HTN)?

qt2d.question: Does the note describe the patient as having Diabetes mellitus (DM1, DM2, T2D, T1DM, T2DM)?

qheart_failure.question: Does the note describe the patient as having heart failure?

qsurgical_valvular_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having valvular disease requiring surgery (stenosis)?

qafib_ablation.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a planned or past ablation procedure for afib?

qbleeding.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a serious bleeding in the past 6 months?

qpeptic_ulcer_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having peptic ulcer disease?

qrecent_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a stroke during this admission or within the last month? (Answer yes for any recent stroke if the date is unclear)

qhemorrhagic.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having any hemorrhagic tendencies or blood dyscrasias?

qbipolar.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with bipolar disorder?

qschizophrenia.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with schizophrenia or any schizoaffective disorders?

qmdd.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with depression or major depressive disorder (MDD)?

qmed_decisions.question: Does the note describe the patient as being unable to make medical decisions? (Answer no unless there is evidence the patient cannot make their own medical decisions).

qchads2.question: What is the highest CHADS2 score mentioned? Answer "NA" if no CHADS2 score is in the note.

qblood_glucose.question: What is the highest blood glucose lab mentioned? Answer "NA" if no blood glucose score is in the note.

qlvef.question: What is the lowest left ventricular ejection (LVEF, ef, ejection fraction) fraction mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no LVEF is in the note, Answer 55 if the lowest value is 55% or greater.

qPLT.question: What is the lowest platelet count (PLT) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no platelet count is available in the note.

qHGB.question: What is the lowest hemoglobin (HGB) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no HGB value is available in the note.

qCREAT.question: What is the higest serum creatinine (Creat) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no creatinine value is available in the note.

qAST.question: What is the higest aspartate aminotransferase level (AST) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no AST value is available in the note.

qBILI.question: What is the higest total bilirubin (TotBili, Bili) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no bilirubin value is available in the note.
